bioghist.p: Francis E. Drouet (1907-1982) was an algologist. He received his Ph.D. from the University of Missouri in 1931. From 1931 to 1936 he was in charge of the herbarium of the University of Missouri, and was employed by the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries, the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and the Comisao Technica de Piscicultura at Fortaleza, Brazil. He also worked at the Chicago Natural History Museum, the University of Minnesota, and the University of Arizona. Beginning in 1962, he was a research fellow at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the correspondence and manuscripts of Francis Drouet. Correspondence relates to Drouet's identification of particular algal specimens; his work on the classification of blue-green algae; his National Science Foundation grants and the progress of those studies; and the publication of monographs and articles. There is a significant quantity of correspondence from Drouet to Bill and Fay Daily, 1939-1982 (Bill Daily was a colleague, co-author, and friend). Manuscripts in the collection include various drafts of the "Revision of the Stigonemataceae," and "Revision of the Classification of the Oscillatoriaceae." The collection also includes bibliographic references on algae, illustrations by Drouet, several glass slides, and botanical specimens. Drouet was the executor of Harold Louderback's estate, and the collection includes some personal correspondence to Louderback and a scrapbook of poems, clippings on Louderback, Drouet, and the actor Fritz Leiber. There is also Drouet's correspondence with Herman S. Forest, a botanist focusing on algae, who studied the developmental morphology of blue-green algae (taught biology at State University of New York, Geneseo); and Forest's introduction to and extracts of that correspondence.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
